lines.text: Chicka, chicka, chickabee. / T'ee an me an t'ee an me. / Ressa, ressa, ressa me, / Chicka, chicka, chickabee.

[translating for Nell to the court]
You have big things. You know big things. But you don't look into each other's eyes. And you're hungry for quietness.
[Jerry plays music making Nell cry]
Turn that thing off! What the hell do you think you're doin'? She's never heard music before.
Hey! Sometimes people just do things! It's called impulse. Try it some time.
It's called doin' what you want when you want to, and not giving a shit about anybody else! I grew out of it by the age of six!
Even caring has an ulterior motive.
Trouble go away at nigh', an' Nell caw Mi'i - an' Nell an' Mi'i - ye', Nell an' Mi'i - like t'ee in the way!
[Sways with her arms outstretched]
She lives here all alone, huh?
That's what hermits do, Lowell. They live alone and they die alone.
Let's take this one step at a time. Stay here. I'm gonna go back inside.
Jerry, I can't let you go back in there. We don't even know what that thing is.
It's a human being and she's frightened.
Well, what are you gonna do?
Talk to her... if I can.
[Jerry found the Bible with the note from Nell's mom for the stranger to look for her Nell]
What kind of deal is this? The first who finds her is supposed to look after her?

[matter of factly]
That means you, Jerry.
Oh sure. Just what I need.

[bemused reading from the note]
'The Lord led you here.' There you have it.
*You* led me here.
You want the Lord to take care of her now?
The last time I saw the Lord was in church of my wedding and look how *that* turned out.
It's called doing whatever the hell you want whenever the hell you want to, and I grew out of it 'round about the age of six!
We shouldn't be watching this.
Why not? I think she's beautiful.
Mmm-hmmm...
You think I'm planning to abuse the doctor-patient relationship.
Are you?
No. Just because I think she's beautiful doesn't mean I want to have sex with her. I mean, I think you're beautiful, but...
Thanks!
No, wait. I didn't mean... I'm sorry...
It's ok, I'm a big girl!
To think I was going to be the one to change her life.
Me too.
Don't you know? You were the first.
The first what?
To need her.
Nothing and everything, it just hits her sometimes.
Do you reckon he ought to be in the hospital?
don't go near those places, unless they pay you a heap of money. Your father is 87 years old, Janet. Just be there for him.
Don't worry. I a-gonna go nowhere.
'Durr murr muh...'.
Only one side of her face was working. You try talking out of one side of your face.
Is this for real? No electricity, no phone, no running water.

[sees a spindle, impressed]
Wow.
[walks up to it and carefully, slowly turns the wheel a bit]
Well, she's definitely overage. So I guess we need to find her an adult protective service.
She doesn't need a social worker. She needs a padded cell. That is one seriously disturbed lady.
Well, I'm afraid that's gonna be your territory, Jerry.
Thanks.

[reciting the letter]
The Lord led you here, stranger.

[seeing the Sheriff's wife crying]
What happened to her?
Nothing and everything. It hits her once in a while.
Is there any obvious cause?
You want a list? Life's tough. But she's luckier than some. Got a good husband there.

[into her mic]
She's been completely isolated. Almost certainly mentally retarded. A blood test will pick up childhood disease and any metabolic disorder.

[to Jerry]
Oh, you carry a blood kit?
You think she's gonna sit there and let me stick a needle in her?

[laughing, then matter of factly]
I'll hold her.
[Paula takes off her jacket]
[discussing what is going to happen to Nell, supposing she needs someone to look after her]
Who's gonna look after her? You?

[disgusted]
Me? Why me?
[Jerry ringing the bell of Paula's boat]
Hey.
You sure can make it, roughin' it like this? I don't see an air conditioning unit. You ok about breathing raw air?
[Paula knocks on a box on the ceilling]
Oh.
I've got someone to cover for me. Everybody's replaceable.
I like it here. It's a quiet place. You've got the right idea, Nell. You live with people, you get problems. First they screw you up, then they leave you, right?
What is it with you and Nell?
It's like... there's no one else in the world. Like she doesn't need anybody. Can you live your whole life that way, or does it drive you crazy in the end?
'Missa' - little. 'Erna' - big.
Tata?
'Tata'. Potalto. Just kidding. Frightened. 'Tata' - frightened. 'T'ee' - tree.

Let me give you a little peek into the future, Paula. One day soon some hiker or fisherman is gonna walk out of those woods with a story about a wild woman. And that'll bring the news reporters and the reports will bring the crowds, who will bring the talk-show hosts. Nell will find she's hired a lawyer, an agent, a manager, and three bodyguards. You think she can handle that?
All the research shows that children who perceive their parents enjoying a good sex-life grow up to have far better sexual relationships themselves.
Is that so?
Yea, that's so.
